author: Jana Stoneman
title: Using AI for Social Good
text:
Using AI for Social Good Most people use artificial intelligence for things like online searching and shopping, chatbots, navigation, image generation, and more. LMU senior Gavin Butts ‚Äô25 wants to use AI for social good.
A statistics & data science and computer science double major, who‚Äôs also minoring in math, Butts‚Äô interest in research was first sparked by a project with LMU Seaver College Prof. Junyuan Lin . The project, which focused on the women‚Äôs soccer team, explored the impact of various factors on athlete training, competition readiness, and performance. Their research was not only part of LMU‚Äôs Summer Undergraduate Research Program (SURP) , but it was also presented in Tokyo, Japan, and it won best poster at the Southern California Conference of Applied Math (SOCAMS). For Butts, the experience also highlighted the intersection of social justice and his studies, inspiring him to pursue research as a career.
‚ÄúThis was my first chance to ever incorporate both social justice initiatives with what I‚Äôm studying, and I think getting that experience first hand ‚Äì like, this is something I can do, and this is something I could live doing ‚Äì that‚Äôs not something I ever considered, and that‚Äôs just something I‚Äôd love to explore further,‚Äù Butts said.
Learn More About LMU Undergraduate Programs Outside of the classroom, Butts, who also serves as the Vice President for Service with LMU‚Äôs Ignatians Service Organization , credits his involvement with the group and its focus on social reform, abolition initiatives, and working with disadvantaged communities, for further igniting his passion for social justice.
Butts hopes to one day use what he‚Äôs learned inside the classroom with statistics, data science, and computer science to explore AI ethics and research other social justice causes, including how AI can be used for prison reform.
‚ÄúI think it would be really interesting to be able to explore how AI can help these people, and instead of using AI to put people in the system‚Ä¶ how can we use AI to help rehabilitate people?‚Äù
topics: Economy, Business and Finance->investment and opinion pieces

author: Kathryn Pomroy
title: Americans More Positive About Social Security Benefits in 2024 | Kiplinger
text: Americans Optimistic About Future Social Security Benefits Gallup poll that shows that Americans are feeling more upbeat about future social security benefits, relative to recent years More Americans expect to receive Social Security when they retire, according to a recent Gallup [survey](https://news.gallup.com/poll/546890/americans-upbeat-future-social-security-benefits.aspx). Yet, 43% of retirees currently expect that their benefits will eventually be cut. The new poll also found that expectations for receiving Social Security benefits vary by age among nonretirees, with 66% of those 50 and older expecting to get benefits. Only 37% of nonretirees between 30 and 49 believe they will get Social Security benefits, while 61% do not. Of the youngest adults, aged 18 to 29, 50% think they will get benefits (up from 34% in 2015), and 48% do not. That‚Äôs the most optimistic this age group has been at any point since 2000. Gallup noted that preserving Social Security largely called on raising payroll taxes of current workers, curbing benefits for current and/or future recipients and possibly raising the age at which retirees can receive full benefits (currently 67 years old). And while U.S. adults have typically favored raising Social Security taxes rather than curbing benefits to sustain the system long-term, they are more likely to favor tax increases now than in the past. Subscribe to Kiplinger‚Äôs Personal Finance Be a smarter, better informed investor. [ Save up to 74% ](https://subscribe.kiplinger.com/servlet/OrdersGateway?cds_mag_code=KPP&cds_page_id=268237&cds_response_key=I3ZPZ001) Sign up for Kiplinger‚Äôs Free E-Newsletters Profit and prosper with the best of expert advice on investing, taxes, retirement, personal finance and more - straight to your e-mail. Profit and prosper with the best of expert advice - straight to your e-mail. Uncertainty About Maximizing Social Security Benefits The survey showed that only 8% of respondents understood [how to maximize their Social Security benefits](https://www.kiplinger.com/retirement/social-security). For example, only 13% of respondents correctly guessed their full retirement age based on their birth year. On average, they said it was 60 years of age. Generation Z and millennials thought the retirement age was 54 and 55, respectively. Also, nearly half (49%) of adults also incorrectly believed that if they filed for Social Security early, their benefits would automatically increase once they reached their full retirement age. Changes for 2024 According to [Kiplinger](https://www.kiplinger.com/retirement/social-security/social-security-changes-in-new-year), on January 1, several 2024 Social Security changes are going into effect, which will impact outline how to maximize benefits and what beneficiaries will receive and how they will qualify. - The Cost of Living Adjustment [(](https://www.kiplinger.com/retirement/social-security/COLA-increase-2024) [COLA](https://www.kiplinger.com/retirement/social-security/COLA-increase-2024) [)](https://www.kiplinger.com/retirement/social-security/COLA-increase-2024)for 2024 is 3.2%. That means recipients will see their monthly payments rise by that amount for the new year. On average, that equals more than $50 per month, per the SSA. - Wealthy taxpayers may see higher taxes in the new year, as the [Social Security tax wage base](https://www.kiplinger.com/taxes/social-security-tax-wage-base-jumps)in 2024 rises by 5.2%. - In 2024, you can start receiving Social Security retirement benefits as early as age 62. However, you are entitled to full benefits when you reach your full retirement age (FRA). - If you are below the FRA and still earning an income from working while collecting Social Security, the SSA will withhold $1 for every $2 above a set amount, which is [$22,320](https://www.ssa.gov/oact/cola/rtea.html)in 2024. Related Content For the past 18+ years, Kathryn has highlighted the humanity in personal finance by shaping stories that identify the opportunities and obstacles in managing a person's finances. All the same, she‚Äôll jump on other equally important topics if needed. Kathryn graduated with a degree in Journalism and lives in Duluth, Minnesota. She joined Kiplinger in 2023 as a contributor. - - The End of Free Returns The end of free merchandise returns is at hand, as total retail returns amounted to $743 billion in 2023, according to a new report by the National Retail Federation and Appriss Retail. By Kathryn Pomroy Published - Stock Market Today: New Record High Within Reach for S&P 500 The main benchmarks notched modest gains in the penultimate trading session of 2023, putting the S&P 500 within striking distance of a new all-time high. By Karee Venema Published

author: Bonzadog
title: Comment on Illegal Marijuana Sales Still Big, Even in States Where Pot Is Legal by Bonzadog
text:
Illegal Marijuana Sales Still Big, Even in States Where Pot Is Legal
By Dan Nosowitzon June 22, 2021
Many assumed that legalization would kneecap the illegal marijuana industry. It hasn‚Äôt yet.
With recreational marijuana now legal in more than a dozen states (and Washington, D.C.), legal dispensaries are common across the country.
One of the assumptions about the legalization of recreational marijuana held that once legal dispensaries were common, the illicit trade would be unable to compete. After all, why would anyone want to purchase something illegally, and theoretically without safety regulations, when it could be found just as easily legally?
This has not turned out to be true. In
California, Illinois, Massachusetts and other states with legal recreational dispensaries, black market marijuana sales not only continue, but often outpace legal sales. Huge busts of illegal operations regularly make the news and in response, California recently approved a $100 million plan to aid the state‚Äôs legal marijuana industry‚Äîan industry that was supposed to be an untapped goldmine.
One of the biggest issues for legal marijuana businesses appears to be a copious helping of red tape. California has a complex, expensive, multi-step and mandatory environmental review process for marijuana growers, under the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA).
According to the Los Angeles Times, about 82 percent of the state‚Äôs cannabis licensees only have a provisional license, which lasts for one year and cannot be renewed. California governor Gavin Newsom has, separately from this $100 million plan, proposed an extension to allow those licensees to transition‚Äîagain, at significant expense and difficulty‚Äîto a full license.
But marijuana farms, far from the ideal of hippie virtue,
have long been associated with significant environmental damage: water theft, endemic animal deaths, destruction of habitat and pesticide drenching. Much of that was due to the fact that marijuana wasn‚Äôt legal to grow for so long; if you were growing marijuana, it didn‚Äôt matter much if you also killed a bunch of native weasels. But the fact remains that these operations absolutely need significant environmental regulation; it‚Äôs just taking forever to get it. The Los Angeles Times reports that some licensees wait multiple years for approval, thanks to under-staffing and limited resources.
There are other problems, too. Marijuana was hailed as a tax wonder for states: a valuable and popular product that could finally be taxed, providing revenue for the government. But those taxes, in addition to the standard cost of regular businesses (labor, rent, that kind of thing), mean that legal marijuana is
typically significantly more expensive than illegal. And unlike with many disrupted industries, the illegal marijuana industry was already generally pretty convenient, operated through texting and delivery. Plus, marijuana retailers in many states, including California, are allowed on a city-by-city basis. Illegal retailers aren‚Äôt allowed anywhere, but exist everywhere.
This stuff is, hopefully, all temporary: eventually the kinks in the legal industry will get smoothed out and made more efficient. But for now, that $100 million could go a long way, provided it actually can assist the CEQA to be quicker.
I don‚Äôt want to be in the black market Cannabis business, I want to be in the Grey market Cannabis business, Keeps you out of jail üò§

EU recorta 10.000 empleos en su departamento de Salud
EFE | 27/03/2025 | 14:26
El departamento de Salud y Servicios Humanos de Estados Unidos (HHS)anunci√≥ este jueves una
‚Äúdr√°stica reestructuraci√≥n‚Äù
que consistir√° en recortar 10.000 empleos.
La noticia fue confirmada por medios estadounidenses, como The Wall Street Journal y CNN.
En tanto, estos recortes de personal se suman a los aproximadamente 10.000 empleados que
optaron voluntariamente
por dejar el departamento desde que el presidente Donald Trump asumi√≥ el cargo.
De acuerdo con HHS, esta reestructuraci√≥n ‚Äúahorrar√° a los contribuyentes 1.800 millones de d√≥lares‚Äù.
Las salidas voluntarias de trabajadores y el nuevo plan restructuraci√≥n implica la eliminaci√≥n de aproximadamente una cuarta parte de la plantilla del departamento, de una
reducci√≥n total de personal de 82.000 a 62.000 empleados a tiempo completo.
De acuerdo con The Wall Street Journal, que tuvo acceso a documentos internos, ser√°n despedidos 3.500 empleados de la Administraci√≥n de Alimentos y Medicamentos (FDA), lo que representa aproximadamente el 19 % de la plantilla de esa agencia, as√≠ como 2.400 empleados de los Centros para el Control y la Prevenci√≥n de Enfermedades (CDC), que en su caso suponen el 18 %.
Tambi√©n se recortar√°n 1.200 empleados de los Institutos Nacionales de Salud (NIH), o 6 % de su plantilla y 300 empleados de los Centros de Servicios de Medicare y Medicaid (CDS), 4 % de su fuerza laboral.
Los cambios tambi√©n implican el que las oficinas regionales se reducir√°n de 10 a 5.
Al frente del departamento de Salud est√° el secretario Robert F. Kennedy Jr. apuntado por Trump. Tiene 70 a√±os, es sobrino del presidente asesinado John F. Kennedy, y no tiene formaci√≥n cient√≠fica. Es conocido por propagar teor√≠as de la conspiraci√≥n, especialmente sobre las vacunas contra el COVID-19.
